author: ark_mod
body:
If you have enough money in a trading account the company (Fidelity, Charles Schwab, etc.) will let you buy stocks on credit. This can amplify your gains - but also amplifies your loses which can easily wipe out your investment. 

As an example, say I have 100k in Fidelity. I purchased a stock and it goes up 10% - it's now worth 110k - a nice 10k profit. However, if I wanted I could purchase on margin (credit) - using Fidelities money I buy $1 million in stock. This same 10% rise turns my 100k + 900k from Fidelity into $1.1 million - I see a profit of 100k on a 100k investment by leveraging the banks money to increase my position. This works great when the stocks (or options) value rises - the gains are amplified.

The opposite side occurs as well. Take the same example - $1 million in stock, $100k cash + $900k borrowed on margin - but the stock goes down 10%. If using only your money your $100k goes down to $90k. You lost 10%. Now with margin - your $100k + Fidelities $900k goes down 10%. However Fidelity is going to cover their loss. They do this through a margin call. Basically they have the right to sell all your assets they hold to prevent loss. They sell your full position - all $100k leaving you with $0 to make sure they get back the money they borrowed you (your now $90k + their now $810k = $900k you borrowed). 

Basically margin calls can wipe out your full position if the stock you bought on margin drops too much. Look at the recent collapse of Archegos Capital if your curious what a margin call in the billions of dollars looks like. Banks registered big losses because a Hedge Fund made some bad leveraged trades to an extreme scale.

author: laern2splel
body:
You should read what Matt Levine (Bloomberg Columnist) thinks about that, he has a very interesting opinion.

If a few corporations (BlackRock, Fidelity, Vanguard) own all the index funds that all people invest in, then they effectively own all the companies in the world. It would then make sense for all the companies to work together to maximize profits in order to make the most money for their common owners. What the are long term implications here of indexing? Does it take away all of the competition needed to spark the innovation of capitalism? Do we really need competition to spark innovation? It will be interesting to see how it progresses.

author: Mister_Titty
body:
Right or wrong, I respect your analysis. 

I would like to try and adjust your thinking in one area: lack of institutional ownership in this case is a good thing. Why? Because as institutions get interested, it will only be a positive. And there's LOTS of room for institutions to enter. Just imagine if Fidelity decides to 'take a position'. A purchase of $20 million will move the stock! Then BlackRock increases their holdings, then Goldman, then Putnam, and so on.

JMHO

author: Keith_13
body:
The idea that someone shorting 1200 shares drove the price down doesn't really make a lot of sense.

You don't even know that the drop in availability was due to someone shorting.  It could just as easily be someone whose shares are available to be borrowed sold some shares (and the rise to 3000 could be that someone bought some; not necessarily someone covering).

Personally I have 33k shares and about 25k are lent out.  Fidelity pays me 60% of the borrow rate and today I was getting 2.5%; I'm hoping that it really has spiked to 40% (which would pay me 24% annualized)

author: Maximusgoobe
body:
Several of my brokerages utilize a proxy voting system, so I get an email with a link and a voting number to enter. I click the link, enter the necessary info (usually a PIN), vote, and all done! I'll also add that I'm speaking from an American perspective, and only for my experience with Fidelity and TD Ameritrade. 

If you don't get it in emails, you may just need to log into your brokerage's website and see how they'll notify you of an annual meeting.

author: joremero
body:
>for accounting purposes you theoretically reduced the cost basis

shouldn't you redo your statement?

for accounting purposes, you reduced the cost basis (nothing theoretical about it)...at least when it's assigned

[fidelity link](https://www.fidelity.com/learning-center/investment-products/options/tax-implications-covered-calls)

"If a covered call is assigned, the strike price plus the premium received becomes the sale price of the stock in determining gain or loss. The resulting gain or loss depends upon the holding period and the basis of the underlying stock. If the stock delivered has a holding period greater than one year, the gain or loss would be long term."

It’s been a crazy couple of months for Fintech companies. Year-to-date, here are the results for some of the most popular names in the industry:

Square: -6%  
Paypal: 6%  
LendingTree: -32%  
Green Dot: -27%  
Fiserv: 2.2%  
MoneyGram: 45%  
Upstart: 135%  
LendingClub: 36%  
Paysafe: -24%

Data from [Dillibits.com](https://Dillibits.com). Chart visualization from [flourish.studio](https://flourish.studio).

author: Detail009
body:
Yeah depends upon how you mean that.  JPM is building out a lot of their own stuff, Capital One, etc...  When it comes to being the piping behind it all, I'm not sure anybody is winning, nor that a bank will win out there.  Core technology/infrastructure providers are likely in a better position.  Fiserv/FIS/Visa/take your pick.

Some smaller banks have really looking to be the backend for fintechs (CrossRiver, Sutton, Avida, Evolve, and so on) but larger ones were late to the party.  I also don't know how many players we really need in that space.  

So far I think nobody is leading in truth.  If Regulatory changes occur re: open banking (which they probably will) then the playing field gets leveled pretty quickly and you go back to the ones building tech as the favorites.  Jamie Dimon has taken it the most seriously for the longest when it comes to banks, I'll say that.  

&#x200B;

My $.02
